awd_titl_txt: Studies of Etching Microstructures on Metals
awd_abstract_narration: This research investigates localized etching phenomena which                    occur in metals and nonmetals.  The program explores the factors                that determine where etch pits initiate and how they grow.  For                 instance, in aluminum and some other metals etch pits can exhibit               oxide passivation at their sidewalls; this leads to etching of                  deep micron-sized cavities with constant sidewall widths.  Sites                of pitting are correlated with surface composition profiles                     determined by scanning transmission electron microscopy.                        Important variables that are controlled through systematic                      processing include dislocation substructure, impurity                           segregation, and vacancy concentration.  The model system                       selected for these studies is aluminum etched in chloride                       solutions.  The ultimate goal is to use the information on etch                 pit initiation gained from this research to preprogram specific                 patterns of etch pitting on metal surfaces.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY
